Evil spirit” = alastor; see note 141
Very similar language is used here about Klytemnestra’s giving Iphigenia and Achilles’ giving his name

note: and tone (humble appeal 985/ vague threat 987–89).
title: As her opening lines suggest, Klytemnestra has to balance carefully here, both in argument (Achilles is not a philos, yet ought to act like one

note: As the ancient audience knew, Achilles did not save Iphigenia (see 1568–76). And he did die in the Trojan War. These lines, that may be construed as Achilles bringing a curse on himself, are part of the revision of the Iliad which runs throughout this play; see above,
title: Achilles is forthright and straightforward; at one point, suspecting correctly that Agamemnon has lied to him he says “I hate as I hate the gates of Hades a man who hides one thing in his heart and says something else
My ally” (philos again) = Agamemnon. Achilles’ concern for using reason and maintaining peace with Agamemnon here is very different from his quickly kindled anger and impulse to murder the king
The warriors Achilles took to Troy; see note 40
Inachos was a river-god and early king in Argos

container-title: Aeschylus’ Agamemnon, Klytemnestra argues that she is the instrument used by the gods to punish Agamemnon
title: so that no phthonos of the gods comes;” see note 93. Sacrificing one’s own child would surely attract divine attention and punishment
The first two goddesses invoked by Agamemnon are divine principles who rule all humans’ lives; the third is a personal spirit (daimon) who intervenes in an individual’s life for better or worse
Klytemnestra’s first words when she reappears after killing Agamemnon are “I will not be ashamed to say the opposite of the many things I said earlier to fit the occasion
The female version of sophrosune (see note 132); here it probably includes not only sexual fidelity but making few sexual demands on her husband

note: Her boldness here prepares for her even bolder intervention later
title: Iphigenia’s speaking here probably comes as a surprise, since Klytemnestra said she would do the talking for both of them 1121

note: see lines 504–09 and note 77.
title: Invoking Pelops and Atreus recalls the curse on the house of Atreus—the killing of children by blood relatives

note: When Agamemnon is wounded (Iliad 11.267–72) his pain is compared to women’s labor pains.
title: The pain and danger involved in giving birth makes women comparable to male warriors: See Medea 250–51 and Loraux 1995:24–43
Since Agamemnon is not behaving as a philos Iphigenia addresses the infant Orestes as the only male relative available to help her—a strategy that creates pathos and subtly shames Agamemnon
The use of “Aphrodite” for the army’s lust to destroy Troy is unusual; see note 87 and above
This speech amplifies Agamemnon’s words in Aeschylus, Agamemnon 206–17

From here through 1402 there are several changes of metre. 1276–82 are in anapests, the “movement” metre; 1283–1335 are lyrics sung to musical accompaniment; 1338–1401 are in trochaic tetrameters, which convey high emotion. The unusual half-line stichomythia 1341–68 further increases the pace and tension

In a solo aria, Iphigenia sings a lament for her own death, a song that would normally be sung by others after her death. This reversal of the conventions of death and mourning occurs frequently in tragedy

container-title: in line 1291 is Priam. Iphigenia seems to be comparing Priam’s treatment of his child with Agamemnon’s
title: On Priam’s exposure of his son Paris as an infant see above
He

container-title: On Iphigenia’s decision and its implications, see above
note: 322; for a comparison with other willing victims in Euripides’ plays, see O’Connor-Visser 1987.
title: The most surprising development in a play full of surprises. As at 1211, Iphigenia speaks up when she is not expected to; here she interrupts the fast-paced exchange to announce a change of heart. Note that the speech continues in trochaic tetrameter, suggesting that Iphigenia is not calmly reflective but excited, even exalted (see 1416
By calling Achilles “stranger” (xenos) Iphigenia reverses Klytemnestra’s attempts to suggest that as Iphigenia’s intended bridegroom he should behave as a philos
All Greece is looking at me now” = a metatheatrical reference. At this moment the whole pan-Hellenic audience is looking at the actor

note: so though echoing the substance of what Agamemnon said (1271–75), Iphigenia is speaking for herself.
title: Editors clean up the awkward syntax of 1381–83, but I have followed the manuscripts. Such syntax suggests that Iphigenia is thinking on her feet, with her thoughts still in the process of formation (a twentieth-century actor would call this process “discovery”
This line is often cut in late-twentieth-century productions
Iphigenia here sees her self-sacrifice as achieving goals coded as masculine (fame after death) and as feminine (marriage and children); see above

note: see note 24.
title: Let Thetis know this
sounds like a reference to Achilles’ complaint to his mother Thetis that his concubine Briseis has been taken by Agamemnon (Iliad 1.351–60). This makes Iphigenia the structural equivalent of Briseis
Black clothes and shorn hair were signs of bereavement; compare Alcestis 818–19
Another indirect reference (compare 1241 and note 190) to Agamemnon’s failure to fulfill the normal expectations of a male kinsman
Here again is the language (e.g., “conduct”) used to describe weddings; compare 609–10 and note 93

note: in English comes from the Latin word for “left”).
title: The right side was associated with good fortune, the left with bad (hence “sinister

note: The same epithet is applied to Helen (with a pun on her name) at Agamemnon 689–90.
title: Iphigenia calls herself heleptolis, “destroyer of the city” and the Chorus echo her

note: Light is associated with life, safety, hope; compare Medea 482.
title: Be a light for” = “give salvation to

This prayer to Artemis can be understood as a foreshadowing of the miraculous substitution known from other versions of the story and announced by the Messenger (1581–95); see Euripides’ Iphigenia among the Taurians 26–33 and above

note: Alcestis seems over at 1005, just before the entrance of Herakles with the veiled woman; see also Taplin 1977:180–84.
title: At this point the play seems to be over. Many editors consider this the end and the rest of the play an interpolation. The text is certainly faulty, and there are many imperfections of language and meter, but the dramaturgy, including the false ending and the ambiguous resolution, seems utterly Euripidean; see above
Other Greek dramas also employ a false ending before a surprising plot development
Achilles now takes a central role in the sacrifice, doing what Iphigenia envisioned Agamemnon doing

container-title: Similarly, in Aeschylus’ Agamemnon the Chorus say they did not see the sacrifice itself

title: Hephaistos was the god of fire and metalworking

container-title: Greek Agamemnon is the object of the miracle
title: The news that Agamemnon has sent this slave raises the possibility that the miracle is a fabrication. Klytemnestra suspects trickery (1616–18); see above
Some translators make Iphigenia the subject of lines 1605–6, but there is no justification for this

note: like the calves at 1113–14 (where the same word is used).
title: Young calf” = Orestes. This is a fairly rare metaphor for “child”; it occurs at Helen 1476, but in this context suggests that Orestes is another potential sacrificial victim
